learning_outcomes.description: Explain electric and magnetic circuits related to electrical machines.
Apply various tests for parameter calculations of models of electrical machines.
Develop equivalent circuits of electric machines for given conditions and analyse them.
Distinguish different modes of bulk electrical energy transmission and their inherent limitations.
Comprehend the distribution and utilization side of electrical energy and appropriate load management strategies.
Develop an overall understanding of how electrical energy conversion, transmission and utilisation work in power systems.

assessments.task_description:
There will be five quizzes to cover the entire course material. These quizzes will be used for giving feedback to students on their understanding of various topics covered in the course. It will be a blackboard based quiz (online) and happen on Monday lectures during the second hour (last 30 minutes of Monday lecture). The deadlines are given below. Only 4 out of 5 quizzes will be considered in the final grading. Students are advised to complete it during the 30 min window, but it will be available for a day to accommodate unavailability of students to attend quiz during the Monday lecture slot (3:30 -4 pm)


First Quiz: August 4 at 4 pm

Second Quiz: August 25 at 4 pm

Third Quiz: September 9 at 4 pm

Fourth Quiz: September 13 at 4 pm

Fifth Quiz: October 27 at 4 pm.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
Lab 1 12/09/2025 5:00 pm

Lab 2 19/09/2025 4:00 pm

Lab 3 10/10/2025 4:00 pm

Lab 4 24/10/2025 4:00 pm

Lab 1, both parts will be assessed at the end of each session. Report is required for Labs 2, 3 and 4.
assessments.task_description:
The practical assessment component of the course will evaluate the students understanding of the operation and measurement of energy conversion devices including transformers, synchronous machines, induction machines and DC machines. This assessment will be comprised of four laboratories:

- Laboratory 1 (10%): This lab consists of two parts, namely three-phase load measurement (Part I: 5%) and Transformer testing (Part II: 5%). The laboratory will be conducted face-to-face during scheduled laboratory sessions, week 4-7 (specific session allocations will be provided on the course blackboard). Check the course blackboard page for specific deadlines and other details. There is no need to submit a separate report for laboratory 1, both parts will be assessed and marked in the lab. Due date: Sept. 12.

For the rest of the laboratories (Lab 2-4) students will write reports individually based on the experimental data given and submit them via the course blackboard page.

- Laboratory 2 (5%): Induction Machines. Due date: Sept. 19

- Laboratory 3 (5%): Synchronous Machines. Due date: Oct. 10

- Laboratory 4 (5%): DC Machines. Due date: Oct. 24

A complete lab schedule, submission and deadline details are available in the course Blackboard site as well.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
This will be an onsite exam and will cover the first five topics, including Induction Motors. This will be a closed book, timed exam conducted face-to-face. The exam will be held during Monday's regular lecture period in Week 8.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT 

may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures on Energy conversion and utilization

Details of lectures are available in course blackboard page. All the lectures will be on campus. The following topics will be covered: (1) Introduction to Practical Power and Energy Conversion System; (2) Three phase power system; (3) Magnetics circuits; (4) Electrical Power Transformers; (5) Fundamentals of rotating machines; (6) Induction machines; (7) Synchronous machines; (8) DC machines; (9) Transmission of electricity; (10) Distribution Systems and Electrical Energy Utilisation.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures on Energy conversion and utilization Details of lectures are available in course blackboard page. All the lectures will be on campus. learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 4 To Week 13(18 Aug - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Practicals on energy conversion devices

There are four laboratory experiments and report writing activities in this course.

In the first laboratory based experiments students are expected to come to the lab face-to-face and perform the experiments in groups.

In the other three labs, for rotating machines, students will write reports for given real experimental data.
